awd_titl_txt: Bilateral BBSRC NSF/ Bio - Modelling Cellular Differentiation in Plants
awd_abstract_narration:
Plant growth and development are flexible and prone to changes in character depending on the immediate environment of the plant. The processes of growth and development in plants depend on stem cells that divide and differentiate, but little is known about the mechanisms that govern stem cell differentiation. Understanding the properties that govern stem cell differentiation into different cell types (termed the cell fate decision process) is important for understanding the transition from single stem cells into mature cells and ultimately tissues and plants. This project engages research teams from the US (North Carolina State University) and the UK (University of Cambridge) to address the complex signals and regulatory programs that orchestrate cell fate decisions. Iron is an essential plant micronutrient which when deficient affects plant developmental processes, and this project will develop mathematical models to predict the emergent behaviors that are seen in response to changing iron availability. This project will provide insights into biological mechanisms common to all organisms and has important implications for agriculture and food security in terms of increased crop yield in response to stress. The combined use of experimental and mathematical modeling approaches will provide new interdisciplinary educational opportunities in biomathematics and molecular biology, engaging students (including groups underrepresented in science) at levels from kindergarten through high school and including undergraduate and graduate students. 

This project integrates experimental and computational approaches to identify gene regulatory and signaling networks that govern the progression of plant stem cell differentiation. The project will employ computational modeling approaches to predict cellular responses to intrinsic and extrinsic cues related to iron availability and its impact on phloem sieve element differentiation. The termination stage of sieve element development is characterized by programmed nuclear degradation. Differentiation of the sieve element is a powerful model for this kind of study because of a relatively rapid progression. Ordinary differential equations will be developed to assess how gene expression dynamics affect the differentiation of sieve elements. These equations will be incorporated into an Agent Based Model to enable the simulation of multiple cells differentiating simultaneously. The iteration of experimentation and model refinement will be instrumental for understanding the genes and networks that govern this differentiation process.

This collaborative US/UK project is supported by the US National Science Foundation and the UK Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council.

por.por_cntn:
In higher plants, vascular tissues, such as the xylem and phloem play an essential role in the transport of water, nutrients, and signaling molecules. Sieve elements (SEs) are phloem cells that, similar to mammalian red blood cells, become enucleated during maturation in order to transport phloem sap throughout the plant. Dynamics in gene expression and cell-to-cell signaling underlie proper growth, development and morphogenesis of tissues such as SEs. Environmental signals also act as fundamental determinants of cell, tissue and organismal behaviors. However, little is known about the dynamics of cellular behavior during sieve element differentiation and in response to environmental changes. The overarching goals of this project were to identify and mathematically characterize emergent behaviors of gene regulatory networks during the ontogenic development of a tissue, specifically SEs. In addition we sought to predict the cellular strategies used to translate specific cell-extrinsic responses into developmental programs within plants. 

 

Using single-cell transcriptomics with live imaging and RNAseq analysis we mapped the cellular events from the birth of the sieve element cell to its terminal differentiation. We then incorporated information about transcriptional regulators, microRNAs, and hormone distribution in a series of ordinary differential equations (ODEs) to identify and characterize the regulatory network that controls SE differentiation. Our molecular genetic analysis has revealed that mobile DOF PHLOEM EARLY DOF (PEAR) transcription factors form a concentration gradient that peaks at the SE and interacts with HD-ZIP III transcription factors to integrate spatial information about hormone and miRNA gradients. Further analysis revealed that SE differentiation was initially repressed by a gradient of PLETHORA (PLT) transcription factors, yet later activated by PHLOEM EARLY DOF (PEAR) transcription factors that activate large-scale transcriptional changes required for SE terminal differentiation.

 

We also built a template for a multi-scale hybrid model in order to identify rules that orchestrate system-level divisions of SE cells. This model combines discrete agent-based modeling with continuous ODE models to describe the expression dynamics of key regulatory proteins and allow for the exchange of information across biological scales. We leveraged this approach and previously developed network inference methods to identify the regulations that control the division and differentiation of cells within the root stem cells niche. Using scanning fluorescence correlation spectroscopy we quantified the movement of mobile transcriptional regulators that regulate stem cell division and added this quantitative information into the model to allow for cell-to-cell communication. By integrating the GRN inferences, imaging, and molecular data with the multi-scale hybrid model described above we were able to make accurate  predictions about the rules of root cell divisions and differentiation.

 

In order to further develop similar models that describe phloem differentiation we developed an imaging pipeline, BioVision Tracker (BVT), to process light sheet microscopy imaging data of fluorescent markers in A. thaliana roots. We then imaged marker lines for an established mitotic reporter under combination of heat and iron deficiency stress. BVT was able to extract at least 10 metrics that characterized expression dynamics of this mitosis reporter and tracked root growth along the course of the experiment.  We then completed a sum of squares analysis to assess the dissimilarity of each dataset. Our analysis  indicated that iron deficiency and heat stress interact antagonistically to affect cellular division in the roots. This response correlated with heat induced repression of known makers of iron deficiency response. We adapted the BVT imaging pipeline to assess phloem enucleation genetic markers and found that iron deficiency disrupts the enucleation process. We also conducted transcriptomic analysis using developmental-specific markers of early middle and late developmental zones of the SEs and found that iron deprivation alters the expression of known regulators of SE differentiation. Using this transcriptome dataset, Bayesian network inference also enabled us to identify another DOF transcriptional regulator, with no previously known specific role in either iron response or SE development, as a key putative negative regulator of phloem differentiation. 

 

Throughout this project engineering students and life science postdocs and students from across the UK and US, including students from minoritized groups, were cross trained in developmental biology, cell biology, molecular biology as well computational and modeling approaches. We developed a new undergraduate research program with a historically Black university, St. Augustine?s University, which led to the training of three African-American students. We also trained a number of K-12 students through the NCSU CAALS 3D and CATALYST programs, the Sutton Trust Summer School?s biological sciences program as well as local science expos such as the North Carolina Museum of Science Triangle SciTech Expo and The Festival of Plants in association with the University of Cambridge.
